chapterMeaning: The Yoga of the Vision of the Universal Form
sanskrit:
न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानैर्न च क्रियाभिर्न तपोभिरुग्रैः |
एवंरूपः शक्य अहं नृलोके द्रष्टुं त्वदन्येन कुरुप्रवीर ||४८||
transliteration:
na veda-yajñādhyayanair na dānair na ca kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ |
evaṁ-rūpaḥ śakya ahaṁ nṛloke draṣṭuṁ tvad anyena kuru-pravīra ||48||
translation: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by sacrifices, nor by charity, nor by rituals, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by anyone other than you, O foremost of the Kurus.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna emphasizes the extraordinary and unprecedented nature of the divine vision He has granted to Arjuna. He declares that this cosmic form (Viśvarūpa) cannot be perceived through any of the traditional means of spiritual practice—whether Vedic study, performance of sacrifices, charitable acts, ritualistic worship, or even the most severe penances. This revelation underscores that the vision was granted purely through divine grace and Arjuna's unique devotion and relationship with Krishna.

Krishna addresses Arjuna as 'Kuru-pravīra' (foremost of the Kurus), honoring him and acknowledging the special privilege bestowed upon him. This statement serves multiple purposes: it reassures Arjuna of his unique position, it highlights the limitations of conventional religious practices when it comes to the highest divine revelation, and it prepares the ground for Krishna's subsequent teaching about bhakti (devotion) as the supreme means of knowing Him. The verse implicitly suggests that what ritual, study, and austerity cannot achieve, pure devotion and divine grace can accomplish, foreshadowing the devotional teachings that will follow in the next verse.
speaker: Krishna
